input:

40:27 Caption: That was a nice football moment. Bastian Schweinsteiger (Bayern Munich) receives an amazing defence-splitting low pass on the edge of the box and blasts the ball towards the roof of the net. Igor Akinfeev guesses his intention and dives superbly to deny him with a remarkable save! The referee and one of his assistants signal for a corner kick to Bayern Munich.
40:49 Event: Corner by Bayern Munich
40:51 Event: Ball out of play
40:59 Caption: Mario Gotze (Bayern Munich) is heading toward the corner flag to take the set piece.
41:17 Event: Clearance by CSKA
41:20 Caption: Thomas Muller (Bayern Munich) didn't manage to convert the resulting corner kick into a goal. He produced a header from a dangerous position inside the box, but his attempt went well wide of the right post.
41:22 Event: Ball out of play
41:35 Event: Throw-in by Bayern Munich
42:20 Event: Ball out of play
42:31 Caption: Mario Gotze (Bayern Munich) slaloms his way past challenges, but an opposing player does well to get the ball away. The ball is out of play. Bayern Munich will have a chance to score from a corner.
42:38 Event: Corner by Bayern Munich
42:48 Caption: Mario Gotze (Bayern Munich) works the corner short.
43:01 Event: Ball out of play
43:13 Caption: Roman Eremenko (CSKA Moscow) produces a poor pass. He attempts to get the ball into the box but it's hacked away. CSKA Moscow get a corner.
43:31 Event: Corner by CSKA
43:33 Caption: The corner kick from Bibras Natcho (CSKA Moscow) is headed out of the penalty area by one of the defenders.
44:34 Caption: Bastian Schweinsteiger (Bayern Munich) reacts well to get to the rebound and takes a shot from the edge of the box, but he fails to get the ball through the players standing between him and the goal.
45:59 Caption: We have seen a few chances and nice movements, but the overall impression of the game is rather average and not hugely entertaining. The hosts were superior in their performance in the first half. They were more active and precise. The home side display their usual fluent passing, while the visitors use their organization to stop the build up and launch counter-attacks.

The home team made a lot of passes and attempted to maintain possession. The away side's tactic was counter-attacking.
    

    #######TASK 
    Provide a factually correct and detailed textual description of the game compiled from the information presented above from different sources, in more than 1000 words.
            "Cap:": represents the captions published in the online portal usually within 30 seconds of the event.
            "E:" represents events recorded exactly after the event happened.
    Don't mention sources of information like commentators or captions, write as if you saw them live.
summary:
On a brisk evening at the Allianz Arena, Bayern Munich hosted CSKA Moscow in what was anticipated to be a thrilling encounter. Bayern, renowned for their intricate passing play and offensive prowess, were set to showcase their dominance on home turf against a CSKA side known for their resilient defending and swift counter-attacks.

The match commenced with Bayern Munich taking the initial kick-off. Right from the offset, the game promised to be eventful, with the ball frequently going out of play within the first few minutes. Bayern Munich's throw-ins were matched by CSKA's, and the game saw several clearances and indirect free-kicks that kept the players on their toes.

In the early stages, CSKA showed a bit of ambition as they had a shot off target and exhibited moments of composed defense. However, by the 8th minute, Bayern Munich had earned a corner, signaling their intention to dominate proceedings. The initial exchanges saw Bayern meticulously orchestrate passes, aiming to unlock CSKA's well-organized defense.

Just past the 10th minute, a noteworthy incident occurred. Franck Ribery's attacking momentum was curtailed by an offside call, signaling Bayernâs desire to penetrate the oppositionâs defensive line early in the match. As Bayern Munich continued to press, Thomas Muller made attempts to burst forward, but CSKAâs defensive discipline denied them a clear sight of the goal.

Nonetheless, Bayern's persistence paid off in the 17th minute. Bibras Natcho of CSKA committed a clumsy foul within the penalty area, and the referee did not hesitate to point to the spot. Thomas Muller stepped up to take the penalty kick and expertly dispatched it into the bottom left corner, giving Bayern Munich a 1-0 lead.

Following the goal, the match saw periods of back-and-forth play. CSKA struggled to break through Bayernâs high pressing game, and though Seydou Doumbia managed to weave through the defense for a one-on-one with Manuel Neuer, Bayern's goalkeeper thwarted his effort with a stellar save. Gianluca Gaudino for Bayern Munich was also active, delivering crosses that caused no substantial threat yet demonstrated Bayern's resolve to extend their lead.

The match's physical nature was highlighted in the 26th minute when Bibras Natcho received a yellow card for engaging in a verbal altercation following a tackle. This incident reflected the burgeoning frustrations of the CSKA players as they struggled to contain Bayern's attacks. Mario Gotze was particularly lively, consistently involved in Bayernâs offensive moves though repeatedly stifled by the CSKA defense.

As the first half progressed, Bayern Munich continued to mount pressure. Bastian Schweinsteiger nearly doubled their lead with a thunderous shot from the edge of the box, only for CSKAâs Igor Akinfeev to make an outstanding save, pushing the ball over the crossbar. Bayern kept launching attacks, forcing corner after corner, but could not find the back of the net again before the half-time whistle.

The second half began with Pep Guardiola making strategic substitutions, bringing on Arjen Robben for Thomas Muller and Robert Lewandowski for Franck Ribery. These changes, aimed at injecting fresh energy and creativity into the squad, paid dividends as Bayern Munich continued to control the flow of the game.

Bayernâs dominance was evident, right from the start of the second half. Robert Lewandowski and Arjen Robben were at the heart of Bayern's creative play. Lewandowski, known for his clinical finishing, forced Igor Akinfeev into a fine save early into the half. Arjen Robben also tested Akinfeev with a towering header that the goalkeeper saved crucially.

Despite CSKA Moscowâs efforts to stymie Bayernâs attacks, they couldnât manage offensive prowess. Bayernâs defense, marshaled by Jerome Boateng and supported by Neuer in goal, held strong, coming out to intercept and clear any threatening balls. On the other end, Bayern Munichâs concerted pattern of play reaped more dividends. Following a well-engineered cross from Bastian Schweinsteiger, Sebastian Rode met it with a decisive header that landed in the middle of the net, pushing Bayern's lead to 2-0.

Moments of flair and skill came from Robben, who time and again took on CSKA defenders, creating scoring chances for himself and his teammates. Lewandowski nearly added another goal, striking the post with a close-range effort after receiving a slick pass inside the box.

CSKA made their own substitution, with Zoran Tosic replacing Bibras Natcho, in hopes of changing their fortunes. However, their efforts were met with continued Bayern Munich resilience. CSKA continued to forego offensive breakthroughs, with notable efforts from Ahmed Musa among others going begging. A yellow card to Alan Dzagoev for a rough tackle exemplified the growing frustration within the CSKA ranks.

Bayern Munich, epitomizing professional execution and superior technique, looked to administer the game. Substitutions bore fruit, and their players maintained ball possession excellently through short, slick passes. What seemed inevitable was Bayernâs third goal, which duly materialized before the game's conclusion.

In the closing stages, Robert Lewandowski and Mitchell Weiser, who replaced Gianluca Gaudino, kept Bayernâs play dynamic. Arjen Robbenâs mazy runs and shots were a constant source of trouble for the CSKA defense. In the 44th minute, Robben found the net, sealing a comprehensive 3-0 victory for Bayern Munich.

As the final whistle blew, Bayern Munich's superiority was unequivocal. They dominated in possession, creating several opportunities and consistently testing CSKAâs defense. In contrast, CSKAâs strategy of counter-attacks fell short against Bayernâs impregnable defense. The Bayern Munich players celebrated an emphatic victory, underlining their capability as serious contenders in the ongoing competition. The home fans cheered their team off the pitch, appreciative of the clinical performance put in by their side. This match was indeed another testament to the brilliance of Bayern Munich under Pep Guardiola.
